bestBHT.bht: Paul, like all Jewish youth, was taught a trade, despite his future path as a minister of Christ. He worked as a tentmaker, which was a trade that wasn't highly regarded or well-paid. However, Paul saw it as necessary, not only to support himself, but also to maintain his integrity and prevent his motives from being misunderstood. He found fulfillment in his trade, and it was a testament to his commitment to honest industry, proving that a minister of the gospel shouldn't be ashamed to work with his own hands.

Henry Alford: He that teacheth not his son a trade, doth the same as if he taught him to be a thief.
He that hath a trade in his hand, to what is he like? He is like a vineyard that is fenced.
The general opinion now is, that St. Paul was a maker of tents from the ‘cilicium,’ or hair-cloth of Cilician goats.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Every Jewish youth, whatever the pecuniary circumstances of his parents, was taught some trade... Paul made it a point of conscience to work at that which he had probably been bred to, partly that he might not be burdensome to the churches.
[Paul worked] partly that his motives as a minister of Christ might not be liable to misconstruction.
To both these he makes frequent reference in his Epistles.
Albert Barnes: The apostle was not ashamed of honest industry for a livelihood; nor did he deem it any disparagement that a minister of the gospel should labor with his own hands.
It was a regular custom among the Jews to train up their sons to some useful employment, that they might have the means of an honest livelihood.
Paul was not ashamed to be employed in [tentmaking];
Marvin Vincent: Whoever does not teach his son a trade is as if he brought him up to be a robber.
All the Rabbinical authorities in Christ's time, and later, were working at some trade.
It was a trade lightly esteemed and poorly paid.
John Calvin: This place teacheth that Paul, before he came to Corinth, was wont to work with his hands; and that not upon pleasure, but that he might get his living with his handiwork.

And he showeth a reason, because the false apostles taught freely without taking any thing, that they might craftily creep in, therefore the holy man would not give place to them in that point, lest he should cause the gospel of Christ to be evil spoken of.
But we may easily gather out of this place, that whithersoever he came, (until he was occupied in the continual labor of teachings) he wrought of his occupation, that he might get his living.
Philip Schaff: This trade, learned in his boyhood, gives us no clue to the circumstances of the family of Saul of Tarsus."
Every Jewish boy was carefully taught a trade...to earn his daily bread in the foreign cities where the chances of war or persecution might transport him.

'Paul,' writes St. Chrysostom, 'after working miracles, would stand in his workshop of Corinth, and stitch the leather skins with his hands, while the angels looked on him lovingly, and the devils with fear.'
Archibald T. Robertson: He that teacheth not his son a trade, doth the same as if he taught him to be a thief.
It was a blessing to Paul to find himself with these people.
So he 'abode' (εμενεν, imperfect active) with them and 'they wrought' (ηργαζοντο, imperfect middle), happy and busy during week days.
John Gill: He abode with them; in the same house in which they were.
He learned a trade whilst among the Jews, with whom it was common for their greatest doctors to be brought up to some trade or another.
Perhaps they were of the same occupation with Menedemus the philosopher, who was σκηνορραφος, 'a sewer of tents.'
John Wesley: They were tent makers by trade — For it was a rule among the Jews (and why is it not among the Christians?) to bring up all their children to some trade, were they ever so rich or noble.
For it was a rule among the Jews (and why is it not among the Christians?) to bring up all their children to some trade.
Why is it not among the Christians?

Paul, having learned the trade of tentmaking, chose to work with his hands not only to avoid burdening the churches but also to safeguard the perception of his motives as a minister. Although tentmaking was a lowly and underpaid profession, Paul found contentment in it. His example showed that a minister of the gospel should not be ashamed to engage in honest labor.

Paul, as a Jewish youth, was taught the trade of tentmaking, which he continued to practice even as a minister of the gospel. Despite the low esteem and poor pay associated with this trade, Paul embraced it not only to avoid burdening the churches and to protect the purity of his motives but also to find contentment and purpose in his work. His example teaches that a minister should not be ashamed to engage in honest labor and that industry is a blessing in serving the Lord.
